original_title: Sri Lanka to make producers responsible for plastic containers
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka will bring laws to mandate firms to collect plastic containers after sale so that they could be recycled as part of efforts to reduce plastic use, Secretary of the Ministry of Environment Anil Jasinghe said.

Sri Lanka is now formulating 42 amendments to the country’s environment law, one of which will be on extended producer responsibility or making producers responsible for collecting and dealing with containers after sales.

“Under the law, the producer of the plastic bottle, companies that use it and customer will have certain responsibilities for safe disposal of the containers environmental and health wise,” Jasinghe told reporters Monday.
“Up to now it was done voluntarily. But we now have to make it legally binding as in the rest of the world,” Jasinghe said.
From June the Central Environmental Authority would also bring regulations for imported plastic pellets.

“Before importing a shipment, the producer will have to file a material balance disclosing to whom the goods were issued from the earlier shipment,” Supun Pathirana, Chairman of the Central Environmental Authority said.
“Through this we hope to stop unregulated plastic and polythene productions.”

The use and unsafe plastic containers, particularly yoghurt cups, has been linked to the rise of the dengue epidemic. Authorities are starting a campaign in schools to combat the use and unsafe disposal of plastic containers. (Colombo/May 29/2023)
